newsitem.title: USA: Wells Fargo shares drop after Q1 results.
newsitem.headline: Wells Fargo shares drop after Q1 results.

text.p: Wells Fargo and Co's shares tumbled after the bank, which bought First Interstate Bancorp in 1996, posted disappointing first-quarter results on Tuesday, causing analysts to slash forecasts for the year.

"The revenue picture is rather slugglish," said Thomas Theurkauf, an analyst with Keefe Bruyette Woods. "When you strip out securities gains and more volatile items, you find a modest compression in revenues and that's a disappointment."
The stock fell 8-1/4 to 256-1/2 after Wells reported first-quarter earnings fell to $3.62 a share from $5.39.

Earlier, Paul Hazen, Wells Fargo's chief executive, said while the bank was halfway to its goal of $800 million in gross annual expense reductions, revenues were held back by declines in its loan and deposit portfolios.
Analysts said the bank's revenue was affected by some customer attrition that followed the merger.

"It points out how difficult it is for a company to simultaneously strip expenses and grow revenue base (after a merger). You've got to figure there will be some customer attrition," Theurkauf said, noting he was lowering his forecast for the year, currently at $16.50 a share.
